prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 1 & 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(4-3) detection in Band 4 for targets 1 & 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center the line for Target 1 in the first baseband, and position the second baseband to provide both continuous frequency coverage and contain the line for Target 6. We place the remaining two basebands in the lower side band for increased sensitivity for a potential continuum detection. Since the lines are very wide (>~200 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest spatial resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~2" in Band 4 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, Target 1 is expected to be slightly extended, with the flux spread over ~2-6 beams. Target 6 is also expected to be slightly extended, potentially over ~3-8 beams. The target sensitivity, set by this object, aims for a 5-sigma detection integrated over its entire spatial extent. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(4-3) flux from our measured CO(1-0) fluxes, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~7 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve at least a 5-7-sigma detection over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) lines (220 and 280km/s for targets 1 and 6, respectively). Since targets 1 and 6 can be observed with the same spectral setup, allowing us to save time on overheads compared to individual science goals, our target sensitivity is set by the fainter of the two objects (#6) at 5-sigma level. The required sensitivity to achieve a 5-sigma detection of the total (spatially and spectrally) integrated flux for object 6 also allows us to achieve a >5-sigma detection per beam in object 1.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) detection in Band 3 for Target 2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center the line for Target 2 in the first baseband. We place the remaining three basebands above and below (two in the lower side band) for increased sensitivity for a potential continuum detection. Since the line is very wide (>~800 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest spatial resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~3" in Band 3 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, Target 2 is not expected to be spatially extended. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(3-2) flux from our measured CO(1-0) flux, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~3.8 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve a 5-sigma detection per beam over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) line (800km/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) detection in Band 3 for Target 3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center the line for Target 3 in the first baseband. We place the remaining three basebands above for a potential continuum detection (two in the upper sideband). Since the line is very wide (>~400 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~3.5" at this frequency in Band 3 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, Target 3 is not expected to be spatially extended. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(3-2) flux from our measured CO(1-0) fluxes, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~3.8 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve a 5-sigma detection per beam over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) line (400km/s) - for which the targeted sensitivity is sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) detection in Band 3 for Target 5.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center the line for Target 5 in the first baseband. We place the remaining three basebands below (and in the lower side band) for increased sensitivity for a potential continuum detection. Since the lines are very wide (>~200 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~3" in Band 3 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, Target 5 is expected to be marginally extended. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(3-2) flux from our measured CO(1-0) fluxes, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~3.8 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve a 5-sigma detection over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) line (200km/s) - which can be achieved with the requested sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) detection in Band 3 for Target 7.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center the line for Target 7 in the first baseband. We place the remaining three basebands below (and in the lower side band) for increased sensitivity for a potential continuum detection. Since the line is very wide (>~300 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~3" at this frequency in Band 3 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, Target 7 is not expected to be spatially extended. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(3-2) flux from our measured CO(1-0) fluxes, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~3.8 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve a 5-sigma detection per beam over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) line (300km/s) - for which the requested rms will be sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) detection in Band 3 for Target 8.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We center the line for Target 8 in the first baseband. We place the remaining three basebands above and below (in the upper side band) for a potential continuum detection. Since the lines are very wide (>~340 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~3" at this frequency in Band 3 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, Target 8 is not expected to be spatially extended. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(3-2) flux from our measured CO(1-0) fluxes, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~3.8 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve a 5-sigma detection per beam over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) line (340km/s) - for which the requested sensitivity will be sufficient.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Target 4, 9, & 10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2) detection in Band 3 for targets 4, 9, & 10.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We nearly center the line for Target 4 in the first baseband, and position the second baseband to provide both continuous frequency coverage and contain the lines for Targets 9 and 10. We place the remaining two basebands in the lower side band for increased sensitivity for a potential continuum detection. Since the lines are very wide (>~200 km/s), we use the lowest frequency resolution (maximum bandwidth for continuum detections) correlator setup in Frequency Domain Mode. However, since even those channels are narrow relative to our line, we bin the channels by a factor of four in order to decrease the data rate. The TDM mode would not be sufficient for our science goals.

Since this is a detection experiment, we ask for the lowest resolution available to optimize phase stability and point source sensitivity, which we expect to be ~3" in Band 3 (C36-1 configuration). At this resolution, none of these objects are expected to be spatially extended. The quoted LAS is a conservative upper limit.

We estimate the CO(3-2) flux from our measured CO(1-0) fluxes, assuming a typical line flux ratio of ~3.8 for "main-sequence" galaxies (e.g., Daddi et al. 2015). This is a detection experiment, so we aim to achieve a 5-sigma detection over the line FWHM, assuming the same FWHM that we measure in the CO(1-0) lines (600, 330, and 130km/s, for targets 4, 9, and 10, respectively). Since targets 4, 9, and 10 can be observed with the same spectral setup and the same pointing, allowing us to save time on overheads, our target sensitivity is set by the faintest of the three objects (#9). The required sensitivity to achieve a 5-sigma detection of the integrated flux for object 9 also allows us to achieve a >5-sigma detection in objects 4 and 10 even when accounting for the primary beam shape. The requested sensitivity thus will be sufficient for solid detection of all three sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In two decades of studies of molecular gas in high-redshift galaxies, we have gained deep insight regarding the gas properties of individually selected, massive galaxies and their parent samples out to z>6. However, a coherent census of the gas content of galaxies through cosmic times ("cold gas history of the universe") is still elusive. We have recently carried out this groundbreaking measurement over a large cosmic volume at redshifts 2-3 and 5-6 through a large, deep 500hr survey with the VLA. By targeting the ground-state CO 1-0 line, this novel study is free of excitation bias. We here propose to investigate the CO excitation properties of this unique, CO 1-0 selected sample by detecting CO 3-2 or 4-3 emission in 10 representative sources in our sample, covering a significant range in gas and stellar masses and star formation rates - allowing us to place them into context with other, known high-z galaxy populations. The outcome of this comprehensive investigation will critically inform any future deep field surveys with ALMA, which will ultimately be able to reach even greater depths than the VLA, but will be limited to selection in the higher-J CO lines targeted here.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
